Headline.Para: The needy receive better support when help agencies are co-located: Government

LeadPara.Para: SINGAPORE - Sharon, a single parent with three children, was facing a slew of problems and did not know who to turn to for help.
Partially blind, the 50-year-old, who declined to give her family name, said she finally approached the Woodlands social service office in 2016.

TailParas.Para: Two of her children, aged 16 and 26, were living with her in a four-room Housing Board flat and she was also looking after her divorced parents. Her elderly mother lived with her and had a habit of hoarding items in the flat, contributing to the stress Sharon was under.
"Back then, I felt like everything was just waiting to explode. I could not work and I did not have money," she said.
But the social service office, which provides financial assistance to needy families, coordinated with Fei Yue family service centre (Champions Way) to help her get back on her feet.

Earlier this month, the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) announced plans to strengthen coordination to make it easier for the needy to get help, as part of the SG Cares national movement to foster a more caring society.

During the debate on his ministry's budget, the Minister for Social and Family Development Desmond Lee said that the ministry is looking at co-locating complementary services. This includes family service centres, which provide counselling, and other help and social service offices. Related StorySchools here referred 900 students who needed help to social workers last year
Co-locating the services in one building will help staff better address the multiple and complex needs of their clients.
Sharon had been unable to work due to a host of illnesses. She has chronic asthma and diabetes, which requires regular treatment.
The two sons living with her suffer from mental health issues. The younger of the two boys had not been attending school regularly as well.
"I kept taking loans from friends and I felt terrible. They were barely getting by themselves," she said.

Enter social assistance manager Lee Hong Lian, 43, of the Woodlands social service office. He worked with a team to help Sharon and her family navigate their problems by coordinating with various agencies.

While the social service office supported the family with financial assistance, the family service centre, together with the school counsellor, monitored the family and counselled Sharon and her sons. The counselling helped her understand her children better, she said.
Madam Aini (not her real name), a 51-year-old divorcee, was similarly helped.
When she was released from prison, she had no money. The mother of two teenage sons also had a spat with her family and was concerned she may not have a place to live.
She sought help at Taman Jurong's social service office, which coordinated with other agencies to help her.
The social service office even found clothes for her while the Fei Yue Community Services located in the same premises at SSO@Taman Jurong donated food rations.
With the help of ComCare social aid assistance and the support of the social service office, Madam Aini eventually found a job as a cleaner.
